speaker: Jo
text: Excuse me.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: I was looking for the Weekly Volcano office... I wished to see Mr. Dashwood?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: A friend of mine desired me to offer a story, by her, she wrote it - she’d be glad to write more if this suits.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Not a first attempt, I take it?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: No, sir; she has sold to “Olympic” and “Scandal” and got a prize for a tale in the “Blarney Stone Banner.”
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: A prize?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Sit.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: We’ll take this.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: You will?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: With alterations. It’s too long.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: You’ve cut - I took care to have a few of my sinners repent.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: The country just went through a war. People want to be amused, not preached at. Morals don’t sell nowadays. Perhaps mention that to your “friend.”
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: What do you - that is, what compensation -
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: We pay twenty-five to thirty for things of this sort. We’ll pay twenty for that.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: You can have it. Make the edits.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Should I tell my, my friend that you’ll take another if she had one better than this?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: We’ll look at it. Tell her to make it short and spicy. And if the main character’s a girl make sure she’s married by the end. Or dead, either way.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Excuse me?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: What name would she like put to the story?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh, yes - none at all if you please.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Just as she likes, of course.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Good morning, sir. Good day.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK. PUBLISHING OFFICE. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: My Beth would like you very much.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Good afternoon, Miss March.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Good afternoon, Professor.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: You’re on fire.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Thank you.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: You’re on fire!
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I have the same habit, you see?
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Mrs. Kirke
text: Kitty and Minny are waiting!
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: My students need me.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Always working.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Money is the end and aim of my mercenary existence.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: No one gets ink stains like yours just out of a desire for money.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: Well my sister Amy is in Paris, and until she marries someone obscenely wealthy, it’s up to me to keep the family afloat. Goodbye.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Goodbye.
slug_line: EXT./INT. BOARDING HOUSE. NYC. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: The decadents have ruined Paris, if you ask me. These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: AMY! I said, “These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush.”
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh yes! Very true, Aunt March.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Don’t humor me, girl. What do they write, your troublemaking family?
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Mother doesn’t say anything about Beth. I feel I should go back but they all say “stay.”
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: You can do nothing if you go back. The girl is sick, not lonely.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: And you shouldn’t go home until you and Fred Vaughn are properly engaged.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Yes, and until I’ve completed all of my painting lessons, of course.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: What? Oh, yes, yes. Of course.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: STOP THE CARRIAGE! LAURIE! LAURIE!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: AMY! You’re so /grown up!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: /You wrote you’d come to the hotel!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: I looked for you and couldn’t find /you anywhere!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: /You didn’t look hard enough!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: Maybe I just didn’t recognize you, you’ve become so beaut/iful.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: /Please don’t.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: I thought you liked that sort of thing!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: NO. Where’s your Grandfather?
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: Still in Germany. I’m on my own, traveling and /having fun.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: /and drinking and gambling and flirting...
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: Don’t tell your mother!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Are you chasing some young girl across Europe?
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: No.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m... I couldn’t believe Jo turned you down. I’m so sorry.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: Don’t be, Amy. I’m not.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: AMY! AMY MARCH! YOU COME BACK HERE RIGHT THIS INSTANT!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh, Aunt March!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: Aren’t we fine, /Ma’am.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: /GET HIM OFF OF ME!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Il faut GO! Allons-y!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: Come to the New Year’s Party! It’s a ball and everyone will be there, including Fred - Pick me up at the hotel at eight - the Chavain! Dress for festivities! Top hats and silks!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Laurie
text: I will! I’ll wear my best silk!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Amy
text: It’s Laurie!
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Aunt March
text: I know.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Sallie
text: Twenty yards of the blue silk as well as the pink. Someone will be by for it later.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Sallie
text: Oh Meg! That would look so lovely on you. I know just the dressmaker to send you to. You’ll be the prettiest wife in Concord.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh no, John needs a new coat for winter and Daisy and Demi need new clothes and --
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Sallie
text: -- and his wife needs a new dress.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: I can’t... it’s, I just can’t.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Sallie
text: He’ll be so pleased with how you look that he’ll forget all about the expense.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: I don’t suppose it’s such an extravagance.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Sales Clerk
text: Will twenty yards do?
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: Yes. Thank you.
slug_line: INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: Fifty dollars, what was I thinking?
slug_line: EXT. MEG MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Daisy And Demi
text: Mommy -- mommy!
slug_line: EXT. MEG MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1868.

speaker: Marmee
text: Beth! Beth?
slug_line: EXT. / INT. MARCH HOUSE. 1868.

speaker: Olivia
text: ...That you do think you are not what you are.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK THEATRE. EVENING. 1868.

speaker: Viola
text: Then think you right, I am not what I am!
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK THEATRE. EVENING. 1868.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m sorry, I only speak English...
slug_line: INT. GERMAN BEER HALL. NIGHT. 1868.

speaker: Young Man
text: Come dance!
slug_line: INT. GERMAN BEER HALL. NIGHT. 1868.

speaker: Meg
text: I know just who I’ll dance with!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: Who will you dance with, Jo?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: You know I never dance.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: I can’t dance.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: Why can’t we all go to the party?! It’s not fair!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Just wear your regular /shoes.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: /These fit last winter!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: My nose will simply not look refined.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: I like your nose.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: Now, Jo --
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: -- don’t touch me, thanks! I already feel ridiculous I don’t want to look it!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: You could be pretty if you tried.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Don’t want to, won’t do it.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: I don’t want to go but I wish I could hear all the music.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: I’ll keep it all in my head and try to sing it for you when I get home.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: Ought they to smoke /like that?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: /It’s the dampness drying.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: What a queer smell - it’s like... burnt feathers.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: There, now you’ll see a perfect little ringlet.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: You’re /ruined!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: /Why is her hair off?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg, I’m so sorry!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: What have you done?! /Marmee I’m spoilt! I can’t go! My hair!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: /I’m sorry! You shouldn’t have asked me to do it! I ruin everything!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: Don’t stare, don’t put your hands behind your back, don’t say Christopher Columbus, don’t say Capital, don’t shake hands, don’t whistle --
slug_line: INT. GARDINER'S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Sallie
text: Meg March! You look so pretty!
slug_line: INT. GARDINER'S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg...
slug_line: INT. GARDINER'S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Dear me, I didn’t know any one /was here!
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: /Don’t mind me; stay, if you like.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: I won’t disturb you?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Not at all; I don’t know many people, and felt rather strange at first, you know.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: So do I.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Miss March, isn’t it?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, Mr. Laurence, but I’m not Miss March, I’m only Jo.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: And I’m not Mr. Laurence, I’m only Laurie.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Don’t you dance?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: I don’t know how you do things here yet - you see, I’ve spent most of my life in Europe.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: EUROPE! That’s CAPITAL! I shouldn’t use words like that.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Says who?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg. She’s my older sister.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: That’s her, see? The girl in the violet /dress?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: /Very pretty.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: She reminds me to be good so Father will be proud of me when he returns.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Where is he?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Volunteered for the Union Army. I wanted to go fight with him. I can’t get over my disappointment in being a girl.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Jo ... would you like to dance? With me?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: I can’t, because...
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Because what?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: You won’t tell?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Never!
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: I scorched my dress, see? Meg told me to keep still, so no one would see it. You can laugh if you want to. It’s funny, I know.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Never mind that; I’ll tell you how we can manage.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: My foot- I’ve hurt my ankle.
slug_line: EXT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. PORCH. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: How will I get home?!
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t see what you can do except get a carriage or stay /here all night.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: /Carriages are too expensive.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Well, let me take you. It’s right next door.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: No, thank you, we cannot accept.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: You must take mine. Please!
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: No, it’s so early -- you can’t mean to leave yet.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: I always leave early - I do, truly.
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: What choice do you have?
slug_line: INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Goodness gracious, what have you done!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Here, make room, /Meg is a wounded soldier!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: /I sprained my ankle dancing!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Oh Meg - You’ll kill yourself for fashion one of these days. Hannah! We need ice!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: Tell us about it!/ What’s he like?
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: /Was the music wonderful?
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Come in come in! Apologies for the chaos: I enjoy baking in the middle of the night! Don’t mind the clutter, Mr. Laurence, we don’t.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Laurie, please.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Can I call you Teddy?!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: You must be part of the girls’ theatricals!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m Amy.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: Hello.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: They could use an extra player, although you’ll have to fight Jo for the male roles or play a girl. Here, have a scone.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Laurie, how are your ankles? Do you need ice?
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Laurie
text: No, thank you, ma’am.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Oh, just call me Mother, or Marmee. Everyone does.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: It really seems like being a fine young lady to come home from my party in a carriage and have maids to /wait on me!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: /I don’t believe fine young ladies enjoy themselves a bit more than we do.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861.

speaker: Friedrich
text: For the writer in the attic: Because you enjoyed the play so much tonight, I wanted you to have this. It will help you study character and paint it with your pen. I would love to read what you’re writing, if you’ll trust me. I promise honesty and whatever intelligence I can muster. Yours, Friedrich

speaker: Amy
text: Jo stands in the back so we can’t see her /cry.
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: /So what if I do?
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Beth
text: When will he come home?
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: He will stay and do his work faithfully as long as he can, and we won’t ask for him back a minute sooner than he can be spared. “Give them all my dear love and a kiss. Tell them I think of them by day, pray for them by night and find my best comfort in their affection at all times.
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: What ho! Minion! I need thee!
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: ...A year seems a very long time to wait before I see them but remind them that while we wait we may all work, so that these hard days need not be wasted
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Meg
text: Born of roses, fed on dew, What charms and potions canst thou brew?
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: ...I know they will be loving children to you, do their duty faithfully, fight their enemies bravely...
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Amy
text: Hither I come, from my airy home, afar in the silver moo -- AHHHHH!
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Jo
text: Don’t laugh! Act like it’s all right! Just keep going! Beth play!
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: ...and conquer themselves so beautifully...
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: Brava! Brava!
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Marmee
text: ....that when I come back to them I may be fonder and prouder than ever of my little women.”
slug_line: INT. MARCH DINING ROOM. LATE AFTERNOON. 1861.

speaker: Railroad Porter
text: Your stop, ma’am.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. TRAIN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Thank you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. TRAIN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: She’s gone? Why?
slug_line: INT. BOARDING HOUSE. KITCHEN/LAUNDRY. NEW YORK. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Kirke
text: I don’t know. She just left.
slug_line: INT. BOARDING HOUSE. KITCHEN/LAUNDRY. NEW YORK. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: But she didn’t say if she was coming back?
slug_line: INT. BOARDING HOUSE. KITCHEN/LAUNDRY. NEW YORK. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Kirke
text: We didn’t have a heart to heart, Professor. What are you doing? Why are you just sitting there? Go dust something. And what about the girls? She was the best teacher they ever had.
slug_line: INT. BOARDING HOUSE. KITCHEN/LAUNDRY. NEW YORK. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I know...
slug_line: INT. BOARDING HOUSE. KITCHEN/LAUNDRY. NEW YORK. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s so hard to go back to work after such /good times.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: /I wish it was Christmas every day.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Or New Year’s, wouldn’t that be exciting?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: We’re a bunch of ungrateful minxes!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Don’t use such dreadful /expressions!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /I like good strong words that mean something.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Well I have to go to school and I don’t have any limes.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Limes?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: The other girls are all trading pickled limes. I’m in debt. I owe ever so many limes.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Will that /do?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /What did you do that for?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I know what it is to want little things and feel less than other girls.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Between that and the drawings I should wipe out my debt.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: What /drawings?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /Nothing!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: I’m just glad that mother doesn’t make me go to that school with all those girls...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Beth, after your shopping, I need you to work your way through the new sums and spelling and I’ll check it all when I get home.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Hurry! I’ll be late!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. CONCORD TOWN ROAD. MORNING. JANUARY, 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: JOSY-/PHINE!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /Yes!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Is there a reason you stopped reading Belsham?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m sorry, I’ll continue.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: You mind yourself, dearie, one day you’ll need me and you’ll wish you had behaved better.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Thank you, Aunt March, for your employment and many kindnesses, but I intend to make my own way in the world.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: No one makes their own way, not really, least of all a woman. You’ll need to marry well.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: You are not married, Aunt /March.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: /Because I was rich and made sure to keep my money.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: So the only way to be an unmarried woman is to be rich.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Yes.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: But there are precious few ways for women to make money.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: That’s not true. You could run a cat house, or go on the stage. Practically the same thing.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Other than that, you’re right, precious few ways for women. That’s why you should heed me.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: So I can get married.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: No, so you can live a better life than your poor mother has.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Marmee loves her /life.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: /You don’t know what she loves. Your father cared more about educating freedmen’s children than taking care of his family.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, but he was right.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: It is possible to be right and foolish.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t think so.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Well, you’re not paid to think.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: I know you don’t care much about marriage now. I can’t say I blame you, but I intend to go to Europe one more time, and I need a companion. How would you like to be the person I take?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I’d like that more than anything!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Then read and don’t sneak around. I don’t like sneaks.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #1
text: President Lincoln.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: No! Father is fighting for him.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #2
text: My father says the war is a waste, we should just let them keep /their labor.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /It is immoral!
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #2
text: Everyone benefited from the system, including you Marches - why should only the south be punished?
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Perhaps we should all be punished.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #1
text: The Marches love a cause.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #3
text: Fine, just do Mr. Davis.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I don’t know if I should.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: School Girl #1
text: I’ll wipe out your debt and give you five more limes besides.
slug_line: INT. SCHOOL. THE SAME DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Sit down. Sit down, Laurie. Latin is a privilege. Please, you have to learn this. I can’t afford to lose this position. Just return to Cicero.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: There’s a girl out there.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: No, there is not.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: YES! Mr. Brooke, there is a girl!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Hello there! Are you hurt?
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m Amy.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Hello Amy, I’m Laurie!
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I know. You brought my sister back from the dance never sprained MY ankle, I have lovely small feet. Best in my family. But I can never go home again, I’m in such trouble. Look.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Mr. Davis hit me.
slug_line: INT./EXT. MR. LAURENCE’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Tell the servants that I want this painting purchased for me! IMMEDIATELY!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Servant
text: She’s in here...
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Jo!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: What richness! Theodore Lawrence you ought to be the happiest boy in the world!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: A fellow can’t live on books alone.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I could.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: What happened /little lamb?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /What did you do?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Just a drawing and then... Mr. Davis hit me.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Christopher Columbus, look at that.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: That’s my grandfather. Are you scared of him?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m not scared of anyone! He looks stern, but my grandfather was much more handsome.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo! We do not compare grandfathers!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: You think he’s more handsome, hey?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh, no. You are very handsome. I didn’t mean...
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: I knew your mother’s father. You’ve got his spirit.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Thank you, sir.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: You are not to attend that school any more.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Good, that man has always been an idiot.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo will teach you.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: ME?! I already teach Beth!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: You’re a good teacher.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Yes, women being taught at home is much more proper, I believe.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Only because the schools for women are so poor.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Indeed, quite right.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I wish all the girls would leave his horrible school and that he would die.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: You did wrong, Amy, and there will be consequences. Thank you so much for taking care of Amy. My girls do have a way of getting into mischief.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: So do I!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Then you should run over and we’ll take care of you.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: And please come here, whenever you’d like. And tell Beth to come /too.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /YES! Beth would adore the piano!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Is she the quiet one?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: That’s our Beth.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Tell the little girl to use our piano.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: And Jo, borrow any book you’d like!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: And may I come look /at the paintings?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: /There is also a lovely greenhouse..
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: We must be going. Girls?
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo/Amy/Meg
text: Thank you/ Please come over/Many thanks/Our apologies.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Oh, Miss Meg! You forgot your glove!
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Well, back to work, back to work.
slug_line: INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. LIBRARY. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: A NEW PLAY, written by Miss Jo March, will appear at the Barnville Theatre, in the course of the next few weeks, which will surpass anything ever seen before on the American stage.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Starring the greatest actress from here to the Mississippi River, Miss Meg March.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: WEEKLY REPORT Meg— Good. Jo— Bad. Beth— Very Good. Amy— Middling.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Excellent.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Well done, sirs.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Mr. President and gentlemen, I wish to propose the admission of a new member. One who highly deserves the honor, would be deeply grateful, and would add immensely to the spirit of the club. I propose Mr. Theodore Laurence!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: No!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Absolutely not!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Come now, let’s have him.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: He’s a real boy!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: We don't want any boys. This is a club for ladies.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: I think we should to do it, even if we are afraid. I say yes. It’s Laurie!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Now then, everybody vote, and remember that it’s our Laurie and say “AYE!”
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Aye.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Aye.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: And, as there is no time like the present!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: You /traitor!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: /You rogue!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Ladies, please - this is my stratagem, I deserve the blame: Jo only gave into it after lots of teasing.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Hear hear!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: I merely wish to say, that as a slight token of my gratitude and as a means of promoting friendly relations between adjoining nations, I propose this set of keys for a little post office I’ve made in the forest by the pond.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Allow me to present four copies of the key, and with many thanks for your favor, take my seat as part of the club.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH ATTIC. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Hello!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Hannah
text: Thank God you’re home!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh Jo I’ve missed you!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: We could have come to get you!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Daisy and Demi! You’ve gotten so big!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I wish you were here to teach them...
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m here now...
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Hannah
text: It’s so good to have you home! I think the loneliness got to Beth, though she ain’t said anything.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Beth, where is Beth?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: She’s upstairs. Oh, my Jo. We all thought she was better but the fever had weakened her heart.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Take this and find her the best doctor you can.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: No, you need this money to live in New York.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m not going back. I’m using the rest to take her to the sea and get her strong.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: When is Amy coming home?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: We didn’t want to worry her.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Does she not know?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Beth insisted we not tell her because she didn’t want to ruin Amy’s trip.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Amy has always had a talent for getting out of the hard parts of life.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo, don’t be angry with your sister...
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Jo! Jo, where are you? I can’t find my other glove!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: TAKE MINE!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Jo we’re going to be late!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Where are you going?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: You’re not invited.

text: I like him, he’s kind.

speaker: Jo
text: Come, Meg, stop petting her!

text: Meg you’re a million times better than she was - although she was a terrific fainter!

speaker: Meg
text: I wonder how she managed to turn white /as she did?
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Jo
text: /Ugh, that Mr. Brooke, could he be any more... obsequious?
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Meg
text: I thought he was very well- mannered.
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Jo
text: Hold on, let me just get this idea down.

text: Beth what’s your favorite eye color?
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

text: Purple.

speaker: Meg
text: Mr. Brooke has blue eyes and an old soul which is much more important than money.

text: Has anyone taken my novel?
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Meg
text: No.

text: No. Why?

speaker: Jo
text: Amy... you’ve got it.

text: No I haven’t.

speaker: Jo
text: That’s a lie!

text: It isn’t! I haven’t got it - I don’t know where it is and I don’t care.

speaker: Jo
text: Tell me or /I’ll make you!
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Meg
text: /Jo, don’t! MARMEE!
slug_line: INT. MARCH LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. 1862. CONTINUOUS

speaker: Jo
text: You wicked girl! You wicked, wicked girl! I can never write it again! I’ll never forgive you as long as I live!

speaker: Amy
text: I’m sorry, Jo.

text: Amy...
slug_line: INT. JO’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: It’s just that the only thing you care about is your writing so it’s not as if I could hurt you by ruining one of your dresses. And I really did want to hurt you.

speaker: Amy
text: I am the most sorry for it now. I’m so sorry.

speaker: Marmee
text: Don’t let the sun go down on your anger. Forgive her. Help each other, and you begin again tomorrow.
slug_line: INT. JO’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: She doesn’t deserve my forgiveness. I will hate her! I will hate her forever!
slug_line: INT. JO’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Good morning ladies! It’s brisk and brilliant and I think the last day for the river - get your ice skates!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: One second! Go down, and I’ll /be right there!

speaker: Amy
text: /I want to come too! Last time you promised I could go!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Is she going to be like this forever?!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862.

text: It was a very hard loss /for her.

speaker: Amy
text: /Is there nothing I can do?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Go after her. Don't say anything till Jo has got good-natured with Laurie, then take a quiet minute and just kiss her, or do some kind thing, and I'm sure she'll be friends again.

speaker: Amy
text: Wait for me! Please!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Hello! Wait for me!

speaker: Laurie
text: Stay near the edge, it’s not safe in the middle!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Ready?
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: HELP! HELP!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Amy! It’s AMY!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh god, oh god, dear god please...
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: No... no
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Jo! Get a branch!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Grab on!
slug_line: EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: My sister, my sister, dear God thank you for my sweet sister.

speaker: Marmee
text: She’s asleep.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: If she had died it would’ve been my fault.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: She will be fine, the doctor said he didn’t even think she’d catch cold.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: What is wrong with me? I’ve made so many resolutions and written sad notes and cried over my sins but it doesn’t seem to help. When I get in a passion I get so savage, I could hurt anyone and enjoy it.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: You remind me of myself.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: But you’re never angry.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I’m angry nearly every day of my life.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: You are?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I’m not patient by nature, but with nearly forty years of effort I have learned to not let it get the better of me.

speaker: Jo
text: I’ll do the same, then.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I hope you’ll do a great deal better than me. There are some natures too noble to curb, too lofty to bend.

speaker: Beth
text: Jo.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh, Beth! My /love!

speaker: Beth
text: /You didn’t need to come...

text: /The sea!

text: I want you dancing by the time Amy gets back.

text: No, no...

text: Coming!

text: You take the other carriage and surprise her - make sure she doesn’t fall in love!

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes, Captain /Jo!

text: /It was so kind of Annie to invite me. Thank you for letting me go, Marmee.

text: Just be who you are, my sweet Meg. It was mine when I was your age.

text: Oh mother! Thank you!

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, pretty things should be enjoyed.

speaker: Marmee

speaker: Jo
text: Don’t forget about us.

text: I won’t Jo, it’s only a week!

text: Thank you again for the carriage, Mr. Laurence. I don’t know how to repay you.

text: Nonsense! Although, there is one thing -

speaker: Meg
text: Anything!

text: It occurred to me today that my daughter’s piano suffers from want of use.

speaker: Meg
text: Does /it?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. LAURENCE HOUSE. SPRING DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: /Shhhhh!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. LAURENCE HOUSE. SPRING DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Wouldn't one of your girls like to run over, and practice on it now and then, just to keep it in tune? If they don't care to come, why, never mind.

text: Oh sir, they do care, very very much!

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Are you the musical girl?

text: I love it dearly, and I'll come, if you are quite sure nobody will hear me, and be disturbed.

text: Not a soul, my dear. Drive on, and keep her safe!

text: Now what dress will you wear tonight, Meg?

text: I will wear this one.

text: I haven’t got another.

text: Only the one? Oh, that’s so /funny.

text: /Not at all. There’s no need of sending home, Daisy - I’m going to call you Daisy now - I’ve got a sweet pink dress laid away, and you will wear it to please me, won’t you, Daisy?

speaker: Meg
text: If it’s alright.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Annie
text: Of course!

text: Everyone is in love with you, Daisy! You have to keep my dress.

speaker: Meg
text: I can’t keep your dress!
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Annie
text: Have fun, little Daisy.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Laurie! I didn’t know you were going to come!
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: It was supposed to be a surprise.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: And what a lovely surprise it is.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Why are they calling you “Daisy”?
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s their pet name /for me.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: /Meg is a perfectly good name.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s just like playing a part, to be Daisy for a little while.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: What would Jo say?
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: You wouldn’t actually marry one of these men, would you?
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I might.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: You’ll have a terrible headache tomorrow.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s a good thing that it’s still tonight, then. Do you like the way I look?
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: No I don’t.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Why /not?
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: /I don’t like fuss and feathers.
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: You...you are the rudest boy I ever saw!
slug_line: INT. ANNIE MOFFAT’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Please forgive me and come dance.

speaker: Meg
text: I’m afraid it would be too disagreeable for you.
slug_line: INT. MOFFAT BALLROOM. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: I don’t like your dress, but I think you are just... splendid.
slug_line: INT. MOFFAT BALLROOM. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I know it’s silly, but please don’t tell Jo. Let me have my fun tonight. I’ll be desperately good for the rest of my life.
