speaker: Meg
text: I’m sorry, John. The silk was the first real expense.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Fifty dollars, while a lot, is not, I suppose, too much for a dress, with all the notions that are needed to finish it these days.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Well, it’s not exactly even a dress yet... It’s just the fabric.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Oh, I see.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I know you are angry, John. I don't mean to waste your money, but I can't resist when I see Sallie buying all she wants, and pitying me because I don't. I try to be contented, but it is hard, and, and... I'm tired of being poor.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: I was afraid of this. I do my best, Meg.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh, John, my dear, kind, hard- working boy. I didn't mean it! It was so wicked, so untrue and ungrateful, how could I say it!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: Perhaps you meant it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: No! Not a bit! We’ll figure out a way to get you your coat as well, and then won’t we be grand, the two of us?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: I can’t afford it, my dear.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: John, but --
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: I need to go to bed.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: And I really am very sorry that you have had to do without so many beautiful things. And that you’re married to someone who can’t give them to you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Hello Amy!
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I don’t want to see you.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Oh, Amy I’m so sorry for how I behaved. Please? Forgive me?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Have you been drinking /again?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: /Only a little, and it’s 4pm, you can’t be too hard on me.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Someone has to do it.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: So when do you begin your great work of art, Raphaella?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Never.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: What - why?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m a failure. Jo is in New York, being a writer, and I am a failure.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: That’s quite a statement to make at twenty.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Rome took all the vanity out of me. And Paris made me realize I’d never be a genius. I’m giving up all my foolish artistic hopes.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Why should you? You have so much talent and energy.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Talent isn’t genius, and no amount of energy can make it so. I want to be great, or nothing. I won’t be a common-place dauber, so I don’t intend to try anymore.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: What women are allowed into the club of geniuses anyway?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: The Brontes?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: That’s it?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I think so.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: And who always declares genius?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Well, men, I suppose.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: They’re cutting down the competition.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: That’s a very complicated argument to make me feel better.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Do you though? Feel better?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I do think that male or female, I’m a middling talent.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Middling talent? Then may I ask your last portrait be of me?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: All right.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Now that you’ve given up all your foolish artistic hopes, what are you going to do with your life?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Polish up my other talents and be an ornament to society.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Here is where Fred Vaughn comes in, I suppose.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Don’t make /fun!
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: /I’m not!
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: You are not engaged, I hope?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: No...
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: But you will be, if he goes down properly on one knee?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Most likely, yes.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: He’s rich, richer than you, even.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I understand queens of society can’t get on without money. But it does sound odd coming from one of your mother’s girls.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’ve always known that I would marry rich. Why should I be ashamed of that?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: There is nothing to be ashamed of, as long as you love him.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Well, I believe we have some power over who we love, it isn’t something that just happens to a person.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I think the poets might disagree.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Well. I’m not a poet, I’m just a woman. And as a woman I have no way to make money, not enough to earn a living and support my family.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Even if I had my own money, which I don’t, it would belong to my husband the minute we were married. If we had children they would belong to him not me. They would be his property. So don’t sit there and tell me that marriage isn’t an economic proposition, because it is. It may not be for you but it most certainly is for me.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: That will be Fred now. How do I look? Do I look all right?
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: You look beautiful. You are... beautiful.
slug_line: INT. PARIS. ARTIST’S STUDIO. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: This is Fred Vaughn, and his sister Kate, and of course you know Mr. Brooke - and this is Meg, Amy, Beth and Jo.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Fred
text: So pleased to meet you.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh, how elegant.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Remember the name “Amy March.” I’m going to come find you one day in London.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Fred
text: Oh, I certainly will!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: I know something you don’t know.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Tell me this second!
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Has Meg perhaps mislaid a glove?
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Mr. Brooke has it? How do you know?
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Saw it.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Where?
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Pocket.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: All this time?
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes, isn’t it romantic?
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: No, it’s horrid.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: I thought you’d be pleased.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: At the idea of anybody coming to take Meg away? No, thank you.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: You’ll feel better about it when somebody comes to take you away.
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I’d like to see anyone try it!
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: So would I!
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: “We could never have loved the earth so well if we had had no childhood in it, if it were not the earth where the same flowers come up again every spring that we used to gather with our tiny fingers.”
slug_line: EXT. BEACH. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: “What novelty is worth that sweet monotony where everything is known and loved because it is known?” How great is that?!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: I love to listen to you read, Jo, but I love it even better when you read the stories you’ve written.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t have any new stories.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Why not?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Haven’t written any.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: You have pencil and paper. Sit here and write me something.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Uhh. I can’t, I don’t think I can anymore.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Why?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s just, no one even cares to hear my stories anyway.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Write something for me. You’re a writer. Even before anyone knew or paid you. I’m very sick and you must do what I say.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Do what Marmee taught us to do. Do it for someone else.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: If you’re walking to Vermont, there is Mrs. Sewell in Keene New Hampshire who will give you room and board.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Susan Robbins
text: You should go home to the girls, I can take care of this.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I need to be here. I've spent my whole life ashamed of my country.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Susan Robbins
text: No offense meant but you should still be ashamed.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I know, I am.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Can I help you sir?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Asa Melvin
text: Hello Ma'am.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Have you sons in the Army?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Asa Melvin
text: Yes, ma'am; I had four, but two were killed; one is a prisoner, and I'm going to the other, who is very sick in a Washington hospital.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: You have done a great deal for your country sir.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Asa Melvin
text: Not a mite more than I ought, ma'am. I'd go myself, if I was any use; as I ain't, I give my boys.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Soldier
text: Mrs. March?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Yes?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Soldier
text: Telegram from Washington Ma'am.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. UNION ARMY SOLDIER’S FUND. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Is Jo back yet from Aunt March?
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: No, I haven’t seen her.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I can’t miss the last train...
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: What can I do?
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: If I may be of any more assistance, please tell me. I will look in on the girls every day, without fail.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Thank you, for everything.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: I have always admired your husband, and I pray for a quick recovery.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh - I’m, I’m sorry.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: John Brooke
text: I came to offer myself as escort to your mother. Mr. Laurence has commissions for me in Washington, and it will give me real satisfaction to be of service to her there.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Thank you.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: While I’m gone, Hannah is in charge - and please remember to check on the Hummel’s, it will be a difficult winter for everyone...
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Will this be enough for the train?
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Twenty five dollars! That isn’t like Aunt March to be so generous.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I didn’t go to Aunt March, couldn’t bear to.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Where did you get the money?
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I only sold what was my own.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Your hair!
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh Jo, how could /you?
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /Your one beauty!
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Now your hair is /off.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Hannah
text: /You look like a boy.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: It doesn’t affect the fate of the nation, so don’t wail.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: I am so proud that you are my daughter.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I was crazy to do something for Father. It’ll be good for my vanity, anyway.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: My girls: I love you more than words can say. Be good to each other. Pray for Father’s recovery. I will come back as soon as I can.
slug_line: INT. MARCH FAMILY HOME. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh, Jo. Is it Father?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: No... It’s my hair.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I would feel the same way.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I know you would.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Laurie, when are you going back to your grandfather?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Very soon.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: You’ve said that a dozen times in the past month.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Short answers save trouble.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: He expects you, so why don’t you do it?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Natural depravity, I suppose.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Natural indolence, you mean.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I’ll only plague him if I go, so I might as well stay and plague you a little longer.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: You can bear it. In fact, I think it agrees with you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: What are you doing?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Looking at you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: No, I mean what do you intend. To do.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Oh you mean with life?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Yes.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I’ve been writing an opera, I’d be the central /figure...
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: /That’s a waste of time.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: What would you have me do?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Go back and work for your grandfather and make something of yourself.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Here.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: When did you do this one?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: It was the day at the beach, when I met Fred for the first time.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: When is he coming back?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: A week or two... he has business in London.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Don’t marry him.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: What?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Don’t marry him.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Why?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: You know why
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: No, Laurie, that’s mean, it’s just mean of you...
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Why?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I have been second to Jo my whole life in everything and I will not be the person you settle for just because you cannot have her. I won’t do it, not when, not when I’ve spent my entire life loving you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. PARIS. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m making a mold of my foot for Laurie to remind him I have nice feet.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Mr. Brooke writes that Father is still very weak, but improving. Mr. Brooke also says Mother is the best nurse a man could have...
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I wish all the letters were from Mother, and not Mr. Brooke.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I’m grateful for any letters.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: I think the deep purple is very fitting for Mr. Laurence, do you agree Amy?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Quite. And the design is very cunning.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: I had to thank him somehow for allowing me to play the piano at his house all the time.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I’ll go into town for groceries - Jo, can you go look into getting more firewood?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: You all haven’t been to see the Hummel’s. We should go.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh Bethy we barely have enough to feed ourselves. Besides, I have to finish this story.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Marmee said /that we
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /Marmee said so many things we can’t possibly do them all.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: But I always go by myself and you haven’t been keeping up with your tasks...
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: We work!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Don’t worry sweet girl, we’ll find a time.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: But it’s been weeks.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: We’ll go soon.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: MY FOOT IS STUCK! I CAN’T GET IT OUT!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Fine, I’ll go myself.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EARLY MORNING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Here she comes!
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Here’s a letter from the old gentleman.
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Beth look what they got you --
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Look!
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: Open the note!
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Jo... read it, I cannot.
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: “Miss Beth March, I have had many pairs of slippers in my life, but I never had any that suited me so well as yours. And they will always remind me of the gentle giver. I like to pay my debts, and hope you will accept this gift. Your grateful friend and humble servant, James Laurence.” OH BETH!
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: “Humble servant” /how lovely!
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /See the cunning brackets to hold candles, and the nice green silk...
slug_line: EXT/INT. MARCH HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: Sir, I wanted to thank you...
slug_line: EXT./INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MR. LAURENCE’S OFFICE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: You remind me so much of my little girl. The piano is yours, I should have given it to you long ago.
slug_line: EXT./INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MR. LAURENCE’S OFFICE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: My child, you’re burning.
slug_line: EXT./INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MR. LAURENCE’S OFFICE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: The Hummel’s are very sick.
slug_line: EXT./INT. LAURENCE HOUSE. MR. LAURENCE’S OFFICE. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Doctor
text: She’s resting.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: How is she? Is there anything I can do?
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Hannah
text: What is it?
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Doctor
text: It’s scarlet fever.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: What’s “scarlet fever?”
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Doctor
text: I visited the Hummel’s, the baby has died.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you all had it before?
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg and I have, but Amy hasn’t!
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Doctor
text: She’ll have to be sent away.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: I don’t want to be sent away!
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I’ll see if Aunt March can /take her.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Amy
text: /I don’t like Aunt March.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Hannah
text: It’s for your own good, child.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Should we send for Mother?
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: No, we shouldn’t worry her. I’ve never wished for money more than now.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: We’ll nurse her and she’ll get better. You’ll see. She will. She must.
slug_line: INT. OUTSIDE BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: “The post office in the forest was a capital little institution, and flourished wonderfully, for many things passed through it: poetry and pickles, tragedies, garden seeds and long letters, music and gingerbread, invitations, scoldings, and even puppies.”
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: It’s all about us!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It is.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: I love it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s just a little story.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: It’s nothing like what you usually write.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: You don’t think it’s too... boring?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: No, it is my favorite one yet.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Really?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Write me another.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes ma’am!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: And keep writing them.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I will.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: Even when I’m not here.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: No, don’t say that, don’t say it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: I have to tell /you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: /No you don’t.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: I’ve had a very long time to think about this, and I’m not afraid.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: No...
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Beth
text: It’s like the tide going out. It goes out slowly, but it can’t be stopped.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’ll stop it. I’ve stopped it before.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. EXT. SEASHORE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: You will get better. Father will get better. And we’ll all be together soon.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. LATE AT NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Beth
text: We can’t stop God’s will.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. LATE AT NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: God hasn’t met my will yet. What Jo wills shall be done.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. LATE AT NIGHT. 1862.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Amy? Come here.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Amy
text: Yes?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Aunt March
text: Come, sit!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Aunt March
text: If you are very good, one day this ring will belong to you.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Amy
text: Really?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Aunt March
text: You just keep being a proper young lady and see if it doesn’t. You are your family’s hope now. Beth is sick, Jo is a lost cause, and I hear Meg has had her head turned by a penniless tutor. It’ll be up to you to support them all, and your indigent parents in their old age. So you must marry well and save your family.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Aunt March
text: That’s all I wanted to say to you. You can go finish your...little painting.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1862

speaker: Amy
text: Hello Aunt March!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Aunt March
text: That Laurence boy was just here.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: He was?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Aunt March
text: What a disappointment he’s turned out to be. It must be the Italian in him.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: When will he be back?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Aunt March
text: He’s gone, to London. Why? What do you need to discuss with him?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’ve just told Fred Vaughn that I wouldn’t marry him.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. FRANCE. RENTED APARTMENTS. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I’ll come home to help with the children, I’m sorry, I’m just so worried /for Beth.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: /Stay. I asked for leave. I’ll take care of the children.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: John.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: And there’s another thing - you should send your fabric to the dressmaker as soon as possible.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: But I /can’t --
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: /No, don’t say another word, I won’t hear it. I want you to have that dress. My old coat will be fine for the winter.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: But /John, it’s --
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: It’s all settled.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: No, John, I really can’t. I sold the fabric to Sallie.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: You did?
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Yes.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: John Brooke
text: I don’t want you to be unhappy.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I couldn’t be, John Brooke is my husband and I am his wife.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Hannah!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What do we do?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Hannah
text: We should send for your mother.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: You were right to send for me, my girls - but you’ve been very good nurses indeed.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s mostly been Jo, she’s hardly slept.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: I didn’t know what else to do.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Hannah, go make a clear broth and Jo get ice - we need to cool her.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: Who is with Father?
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: John is staying with him.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: We need to change the linens.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Don’t go quietly, fight!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Please fight to the end, be LOUD! Don’t just quietly go away!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Marmee! Marmee!
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Jo
text: Merry Christmas, Beth.
slug_line: THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862.

speaker: Laurie
text: And here’s another Christmas gift for the March family!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. AFTEROON. 1862.

speaker: Mr. March
text: My little women. How you’ve grown, and how proud I am of you. Each of you. Merry Christmas, my dears.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. AFTEROON. 1862.

speaker: Marmee
text: Thank god, thank god you’re home. Now I can be angry with you in person.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. AFTEROON. 1862.

speaker: Meg
text: I can’t believe today is my wedding day!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: Me neither.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: What’s wrong?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: Nothing.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: Jo...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: We can leave. We can leave right now.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: What?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: I can make money: I’ll sell stories, I’ll do anything - cook, clean, work in a factory. I can make a life for us.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: But, Jo..
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: And you, you should be an actress and have a life on the stage. Let’s run away together.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: I want to get married.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: WHY?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: I love him.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: You will be bored of him in two years and we will be interesting forever.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: Just because my dreams are not the same as yours doesn’t mean they’re unimportant.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: I want a family and a home and I’m not scared of working and struggling, but I want to do it with John.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: I just hate that you’re leaving me.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: Oh, Jo, I’m not leaving you. Besides, one day it will be your turn.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Jo
text: I’d rather be a free spinster and paddle my own canoe. I can’t believe childhood is over.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Meg
text: It was going to end one way or another. And what a happy end.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865

speaker: Mr. March
text: What excessive promises, giving yourself away to get the other. What a thing, what a gift, always given before it is known the cost or the reward.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Well, I hope you’re happy. Now that you’ve ruined your life, just like your Mother did by marrying your father.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Mr. March
text: Dear Sister, you are too kind. And thank you for today’s festivities.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: You are most welcome.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Meg
text: Thank you Aunt March.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Oh, oh, I don’t like to be... KISSED!
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Meg
text: Oh, I’m sorry.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: You’ll be sorry when you’ve tried love in a cottage and found it a failure!
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Meg
text: It can’t be worse than some people find in big houses.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: I understood your meaning, my dear.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: I don’t miss a THING.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Marmee
text: You are not entirely wrong.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: I may not always be right, but I am NEVER wrong.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Aunt March
text: Thank goodness, here’s the only sane member of the family. I really can’t take any more of this.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Amy
text: Marmee! Marmee! Aunt March is going to Europe /and
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Jo
text: /wants me to go with her! How wonderful! Now I know why I spent all those BORING hours reading to her!
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Amy
text: No, she... she wanted me to come. As her companion.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Jo
text: Europe? With you?
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Amy
text: She wants me to work on my art, and my French, of course.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh... I, that’s wonderful Amy.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865.

speaker: Jo
text: Meg married, Amy off to Europe, now that you’re a graduate, you’ll be off on a long holiday - I’m not good like Beth so I’m angry and restless.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: You don’t have to stay here.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: Why? Should we run off and join a pirate ship?
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: No, Teddy -- please don’t.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: It’s no use Jo; we’ve got to have it out..
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: No, no, /we don’t...
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: I’ve loved you ever since I’ve known you Jo -- I couldn’t help it, and you’ve been so good to me -- I’ve tried to show it but you wouldn’t let me; now I’m going to make you hear and give me an answer because I can’t go on like this any longer.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: I wanted to save you from this, I thought /you’d understand.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: /I’ve worked hard to please you, and I gave up billiards and everything you didn’t like, and waited and never complained for I hoped you’d love me, though I’m not half good enough --
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, you are, you’re a great deal too good for me, and I’m so grateful to you and so proud of you, I don’t see why I... I can’t love you as you want me to.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: You can’t?
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: I can’t change the feeling and it would be a lie to say I do when I don’t. I’m so sorry, Teddy, so desperately sorry, but I can’t help it...
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: I can’t love any one else.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: It would be a disaster if we married, we’d be miserable! We both have such quick tempers --
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: -- If you loved me Jo, I would be a perfect saint!
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: I can’t - I’ve tried it and failed.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: Everyone expects it -- Grandpa and your family, Jo say you will and let’s be happy!
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: I can’t say “Yes” truly so I won’t say it at all.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: You’ll see that I’m right, eventually, and you’ll thank me for it.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: I’ll be hanged if I do!
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: You’ll find some lovely accomplished girl, who will adore you, and make a fine mistress for your fine house. I wouldn’t. I’m homely and awkward and odd and you’d be ashamed of me and we would quarrel - we can’t help it even now! - I’d hate elegant society and you’d hate my scribbling and we would be unhappy and wish we hadn’t done it and everything will be horrid.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: Anything more?
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: Nothing more -- except that... I don’t believe I will ever marry. I’m happy as I am, and love my liberty too well to be in any hurry to give it up.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Laurie
text: You will care for somebody, and you’ll love him tremendously, and live and die for him. I know you will, it’s your way, and you will and I’ll watch.
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Jo
text: Teddy..
slug_line: EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866.

speaker: Marmee
text: I hope I’m not disturbing your writing...
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t do that anymore. It didn’t save her.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: You are much too lonely here, Jo. Wouldn’t you like to go back to New York? What about your friend - Friedrich, was that his name?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I ruined our friendship with my temper, just as I ruin everything.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: I doubt a sincere friend would be deterred.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I wish that were true. If I were a girl in a book, this would all be so easy, I’d give up the world happily.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Laurie is returning, you know.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: He is?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: There was a letter from Amy, she’s coming home: She was devastated about Beth and Aunt March is very ill - but Laurie will be accompanying them on the journey home.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: That’s good of him.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: What is it?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Perhaps... perhaps I was too quick in turning him down.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Do you love him?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: If he asked me again, I think I would say yes... Do you think he’ll ask me again?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: But do you love him?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I know that I care more to be loved. I want to be loved.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: That is not the same as loving.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Women have minds and souls as well as hearts, ambition and talent as well as beauty and I’m sick of being told that love is all a woman is fit for. But... I am so lonely.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I couldn’t let you travel alone with Aunt March being so sick - even if you despise me.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh, Laurie, I don’t despise you.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Beth was the best of us.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m not marrying Fred Vaughn.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I heard... Amy...
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: It was not for you it was for myself. You are under no obligation to say anything or do anything, it was because I didn’t love him as I should.
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: You don’t have to say anything, we never need to talk about it, we don’t have to talk about --
slug_line: EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: My dear Teddy, I miss you more than I can express.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE ATTIC. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: ...I used to think the worst fate was to be a wife, I was young and stupid. Now I have changed. The worst fate is to live my life without you in it. I was wrong to turn you down and to run away to New York.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: JO... JO... JO...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. STREETS OF NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Laurie
text: Jo? Wake up!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh Teddy! My Teddy!
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Dear Jo, are you glad to see me then?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Glad, my blessed boy, is too small! Words can’t express it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Oh thank heaven, I was worried, well, anyway, I wanted a moment with you alone.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, of course. Here, come sit.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: How’s Amy?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Did she bother you all the way from Europe with her preening?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes, but I love it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Where is she now? Did she not come straight home?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Your mother’s got her down at Meg’s, we stopped there by the way, and there was no getting my wife out of their clutches.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Your... your what?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Now I’ve done it! It was meant to be a surprise.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What surprise?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Well, we were engaged, and we were going to wait... that is to say, now we are man and wife.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: You and... Amy.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: It all happened very fast.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Are you - in love?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes. Jo, I want to say one thing, and then we’ll put it away forever. I have always loved you; but the love I feel for Amy is different - you were right - we would have killed each other.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I think it was meant this way.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Oh, Teddy.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: No one ever calls me that but you.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What does Amy call you?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: My Lord.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: That’s like her... Well, you look deserving of it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Can we - can we still be friends?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Of course, my boy, always.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Laurie told you?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Amy, I’m so happy for you. It was meant to be.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh, I’m so relieved - I couldn’t write because it all happened so quickly and then, really, I was worried you’d be angry.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: No, no.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: So you aren’t? Angry?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Life is too short to be angry at one’s sisters.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I really miss her...
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I know.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Mr. Laurence?
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: Jo!
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Laurence
text: I couldn’t bring myself to... The house doesn’t seem right without her and I couldn’t go in knowing she wouldn’t be there.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I know I am not half so good as my sister, but I’ll be a friend to lean on, if you’ll let me.
slug_line: EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Dear Mr. Dashwood: Enclosed are the first few chapters of a piece I’ve only begun working on. It could suit as a story for young people, but I think it is probably quite boring. However, I’m sending it to you just in case it has something of value, though I doubt it.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM/ATTIC. NIGHT/DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I thought she hated me.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: She could still hate you and leave you the house!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What about you and John?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: No, I don’t need a grand estate.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: For heaven’s /sake!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: /What are you doing?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I should sell it, but I’d love to do something that would really make Aunt March turn in her grave.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I wouldn’t mind that.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: /Girls!
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: /A nice turning, just a rotation, nothing terrible.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: What will you do?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’d like to open a school. We never had a proper school, and now there are women’s colleges opening - there should be a school. For Daisy.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: And what will Demi do?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’ll open a school for boys and girls, both.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: What about writing?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What /about it?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: What are you working on?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I started something... but I don’t think it’s very good.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Everyone likes what you write.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: No, they don’t.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I do.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s just about our little life.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: So?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Who will be interested in a story of domestic struggles and joys? It doesn’t have any real importance.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Maybe we don’t see those things as important because people don’t write about them.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: No, writing doesn’t confer importance, it reflects it.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I’m not sure. Perhaps writing will make them more important.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: When did you become so wise?
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: I always have been, you were just too busy noticing my faults.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: Which weren’t there, of course.
slug_line: INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Dear Miss March: I have read the chapters you sent, and I have to agree that they aren’t very promising. But, please send us more stories of the scandalous variety, if you have any.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK PUBLISHING OFFICE. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Or, shall I say, your friend can. My apologies for the joke, I couldn’t help it.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo! Come down!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Coming! I’m starving!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo, you might want to wait..
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: But I’m famished.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: Jo, dear, you have a guest.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t know anyone.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I am so sorry to intrude.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s you!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Hello.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Jo
text: Hello. I’m Josephine March. Jo.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Mrs. Kirke
text: Jo! Is that you?! Come in, come in!
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Mrs. Kirke
text: Your mother says that you’re a writer — how wonderful! I keep a diary, you know. This is Kitty and Minny. SMILE GIRLS. I see you’ve met our professor, he’s a very accomplished man, actually, it’s an interesting group here, lots of intellectuals and Europeans. You know I never thought I’d run a boarding house but here I am! How is that sweet mother of yours? She always had such great height, I never had that, she could reach anything...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Jo, I hope it is all right, I got your address from Mrs. Kirke -
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Laurie
text: Who are you? Who is he?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I’m so sorry to intrude, I was close by and thought I’d, but I’ll be going...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Amy
text: - Please stay! We have more than enough room.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Laurie
text: Can someone tell me who he is!?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I don’t want to be a burden.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Meg
text: It’s no burden at all.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, of course. Please.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Laurie
text: I’m Laurie. And who are you?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I am Friedrich Bhaer.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Jo
text: We were at the same boarding house together in New York.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Hannah
text: Oh JO, he’s VERY handsome.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Mr. March
text: And you intend to stay in New York?
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: No, I’ve been offered a professorship in California - and as I have nothing keeping me here, I thought I might go West. It is new there, and they are less particular about immigrants.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Mr. March
text: Perhaps I should go West...
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Marmee
text: You aren’t an immigrant, so perhaps you should stay home.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Mr. March
text: Oh, I’m going.
slug_line: THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867.

speaker: Friedrich
text: This is a beautiful instrument. Which one of you plays?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: It was my sister, Beth.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: We all play a little.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: But none so well as her...
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: It is very hard to lose a sister. I’m sorry.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. March
text: Do you play?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I do, yes.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Marmee
text: It would make us so happy if you played now, she wouldn’t want the piano to sit silent.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: I don’t wish to offend.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. March
text: Not in the least.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Jo, if you ever come to California, I would love to see you.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I don’t know that I will, but thank you.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Well, yes... goodbye.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: Goodbye.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: What?! Why are you all looking at me like that?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. March
text: What a wonderful man. I hope he comes again, he would be a terrific friend for me.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Oh Father, he wasn’t here for you!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. March
text: No?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Jo! You love him!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I do not!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: You do too! I may be half as smart as you are but I can see it so plainly, you love him. I have never seen you happier. What else is love? Doesn’t she love him Mr. Laurence?
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: That’s a good instinct, you love him.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: Go get him. Laurie prepare the horses. We can catch him before he gets to the train.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: I’m coming too.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: I’m not going!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Meg
text: You are. Amy is right.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: I never thought I’d prepare a carriage to help Jo March go after a man, but I like it.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: He’s moving to California!
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: That’s a fiction. He was practically begging for a reason to stay.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Jo
text: But it’s raining outside.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: It doesn’t matter! Put on a better dress. Follow me.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: LAURIE. STOP STANDING THERE AND GO GET THE HORSES READY.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Laurie
text: Yes, my love.
slug_line: INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
text: You never ask about my mother even when you know I’ve seen her.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: I assume she’s still alive.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
text: But I ask after your mother.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: And I have no idea why.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
text: You’re willfully missing the point.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: That’s true.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: What have they gotten into now?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mrs. Dashwood
text: I have no idea.
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Dashwood Girl #1
text: Father are you publishing/ this?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Dashwood Girl #2
text: /What happens to the Little Women?
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Dashwood Girl #3
text: Tell me you have the rest of the book!
slug_line: INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Amy
text: GO! Find him!
slug_line: INT/EXT. CARRIAGE./TRAIN STATION. NIGHT. 1869.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Frankly, I don’t see why she didn’t marry the neighbor.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Because the neighbor married her sister!
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Right, of course. So, who does she marry?
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: No one. She doesn’t marry either of them.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: No. No, no, no, that won’t work at all.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: She says the whole book that she doesn’t want to marry.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: WHO CARES! Girls want to see women MARRIED. Not CONSISTENT.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: It isn’t the right ending.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: The right ending is the one that sells.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: If you end your delightful book with your heroine a spinster, no one will buy it. It won’t be worth printing.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: I suppose marriage has always been an economic proposition. Even in fiction.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: It’s romance!
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s mercenary.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Just end it that way, will you?
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Fine.
slug_line: INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Friedrich
text: Jo!
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Friedrich
text: Jo, why are you crying?
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Jo
text: Because -- because you are going away.
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Friedrich
text: I would never leave if you wished me to stay.
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Jo
text: I wish you would stay.
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Friedrich
text: But, but I have nothing to give you but my full heart and these empty hands.
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Jo
text: They aren’t empty now.
slug_line: THE PRESENT IS NOW THE PAST. OR MAYBE FICTION. EXT. TRAIN. EVENING. 1869

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: I love it. It’s so romantic. “Your hands aren’t empty now.” It makes me emotional.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Thanks.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: We can call the chapter “Under the Umbrella.”
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: It’s good.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Perfect! Now there is the question of the contract... I’m prepared to give you 5% of the royalties.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: So I get 5% of the profit?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: 5% of the net profits. After I re- coup.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: What about a payment, upfront?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: I’m taking the risk in printing this book.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Yes, but, but it’s my book.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: If it works, then we’ll both make money. If not, then I won’t go under.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: So I get nothing? If it fails?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: No, I’ll give you $500 dollars right now to buy out the copyright.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: The copyright?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: It’s the right for re-printing, that sort of thing, sequels, the characters for other stories.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Might that be worth something?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Well, again, only if it’s a success.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: I see. It seems like something I would want to own.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Doesn’t your family need the money more immediately?
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: They do, which is why I wanted upfront payment.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: I’ll only pay for the copyright.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: You keep your $500, and I’ll keep the copyright, thank you. Also, I want ten percent of royalties.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Five point five percent and that is very generous.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Nine percent.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Six percent -- and that’s it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: If I’m going to sell my heroine into marriage for money, I might as well get some of it.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: Six point six percent.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: Done.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Mr. Dashwood
text: And you don’t need to decide about the copyright now.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.

speaker: Jo
text: I’ve decided. I want to own my own book.
slug_line: THE PRESENT. INT. PUBLISHING HOUSE. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1870.
